_meta.disclaimer: This content provides general legal information based on UK housing law. It is not a substitute for professional legal advice. Always verify current provisions at legislation.gov.uk.
_meta.notes: Primary RAG knowledge base. Source URLs must link to legislation.gov.uk or official government resources. Every document must have at least one verified source.

documents.title: Section 21 'No-Fault' Evictions Abolished
documents.content: The Renters' Rights Act 2025 abolishes Section 21 of the Housing Act 1988, so landlords can no longer evict assured tenants without giving a lawful reason. All assured shorthold tenancies automatically convert into open-ended periodic assured tenancies, with no fixed end date. Any Section 21 notice served after commencement is legally invalid and cannot be relied on by a landlord to obtain a possession order from the county court. Landlords who wish to regain possession must instead use Section 8 or another lawful ground and follow the full court process.
actions_tenant: Do NOT leave the property — the notice is invalid.
Check the date on any Section 21 notice and confirm it was served after the Renters' Rights Act 2025 commenced, when such notices became unlawful.
Call Shelter helpline: 0808 800 4444 to get urgent advice on your rights under the Renters' Rights Act 2025.
Contact Citizens Advice on 0800 144 8848 or your local law centre and show them the notice for independent legal guidance.
Write to your landlord (by email or letter) stating clearly that a Section 21 notice is no longer valid in England and that you will remain until a court orders otherwise.
If you feel pressured or threatened to leave, contact your local council housing team and ask for the tenancy relations officer to intervene.
actions_landlord: Stop using any Section 21 'no-fault' eviction notices, as they are invalid and unenforceable.
Review your reasons for wanting possession and, if appropriate, identify the correct Section 8 ground or other lawful route before taking any action.
Take independent legal advice before serving a notice and ensure you follow the proper statutory procedure, including using the correct form and applying to court.
Avoid pressuring or harassing tenants to leave, as this may amount to unlawful eviction or harassment and expose you to criminal or civil penalties.

documents.title: Section 8 Grounds for Possession and Notice Periods
documents.content: Where a landlord seeks possession after the abolition of Section 21, they must rely on one or more grounds under Section 8 of the Housing Act 1988 as amended by the Renters' Rights Act 2025. Ground 1 (landlord or close family member wants to live in the property) and Ground 1A (landlord wishes to sell) each require at least four months' notice and cannot be used within the first 12 months of the tenancy. Ground 6 covers demolition or substantial reconstruction, while Ground 8 is a mandatory ground where at least two months' rent is unpaid both at the date of the Section 8 notice and at the court hearing. Grounds 14 and 14A relate to antisocial behaviour and domestic abuse respectively and can allow faster action, but in all cases a landlord must serve the correct notice (Form 3), observe the statutory notice period, and obtain a possession order from the court before a tenant has to leave.
actions_tenant: Read the notice carefully and identify which specific Section 8 ground or grounds your landlord is relying on (for example Ground 8 for rent arrears or Ground 14 for antisocial behaviour).
Check that the landlord has used Form 3 and given at least the correct notice period for that ground, including four months for Grounds 1 and 1A.
Understand that you do NOT have to leave on the expiry date of the notice and can remain in the property until and unless a court makes a possession order.
Gather evidence relevant to the alleged ground, such as rent payment records, bank statements, or witness statements, and take these to any court hearing.
Contact Shelter (0808 800 4444) or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) as soon as you receive the notice to get help preparing your response.
Attend the court hearing or ask a representative to attend for you so the judge hears your side and can consider any errors in the notice or grounds.
actions_landlord: Decide which Section 8 ground or combination of grounds applies to your situation and check that you meet all the legal conditions, especially for Ground 8 rent arrears.
Serve a properly completed Form 3 with clear details of the grounds, dates and arrears, and give at least the minimum notice period for each ground, including four months for Grounds 1 and 1A.
Respect the rule that Grounds 1 and 1A cannot be used in the first 12 months of the tenancy and that you must not re-let the property within 12 months of recovering possession on these grounds.
Apply to the county court for a possession order if the tenant does not leave, and do not attempt to evict or change the locks yourself.
Keep full written records of rent payments, communications, and any antisocial behaviour complaints to support your case in court.

documents.title: Illegal Eviction and Harassment under the Protection from Eviction Act 1977
documents.content: It is a criminal offence under the Protection from Eviction Act 1977 for a landlord or agent to unlawfully deprive a residential occupier of their home, for example by changing the locks, removing belongings, or using threats or violence instead of obtaining a court order. Cutting off gas, electricity or water, entering without permission, or persistent harassment and intimidation designed to make a tenant leave can also amount to illegal eviction or unlawful harassment. Under the Renters' Rights Act 2025, local authorities may impose civil penalties of up to £35,000 on landlords who carry out or permit illegal eviction, and tenants can claim compensation in the county court.
keywords: locked out locks changed changed locks
utilities cut no electricity no gas no water
illegal eviction kicked out forced out
cannot get back into my home
told to leave tonight or else
actions_tenant: CALL THE POLICE IMMEDIATELY — illegal eviction is a criminal offence and you can dial 999 in an emergency or 101 if it is not urgent.
If you are still inside the property, state clearly that you will not leave without a court order and ask the police to attend if the landlord is trying to force you out.
If you are locked out, call the police and your local council's emergency housing or homelessness service, explaining that you have been illegally evicted.
Take photos or videos of any changed locks, dumped belongings, damaged doors, or messages from the landlord, and write down dates, times, and what was said.
Call Shelter's emergency housing advice line on 0808 800 4444 and ask for urgent help with illegal eviction and temporary accommodation.
Contact your local council housing options team and ask to speak to the tenancy relations officer, who can take enforcement action against the landlord.
Seek legal advice from a legal aid housing solicitor or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) about claiming compensation and an injunction to regain entry if needed.
actions_landlord: Never change the locks, remove belongings, cut off utilities, or physically or verbally intimidate a tenant to make them leave; these actions can be criminal offences under the Protection from Eviction Act 1977.
Understand that illegal eviction can lead to prosecution, unlimited fines and possible imprisonment, as well as civil penalties of up to £35,000 under the Renters' Rights Act 2025.
Always follow the lawful eviction process by serving the correct notice, applying to court, and using county court bailiffs or High Court enforcement officers if a warrant is granted.
If you are unsure about your rights, take advice from a specialist housing solicitor or landlord association before taking any steps towards eviction.

documents.title: Rent Increases Using Section 13 Notices
documents.content: Under the Renters' Rights Act 2025 and amendments to the Housing Act 1988, landlords of assured periodic tenancies can normally increase the rent only once in any 12-month period by serving a valid Section 13 notice. The tenant must be given at least two months' written notice of the proposed new rent, and any increase should reflect a fair market rent for similar properties in the area. Rent review clauses in tenancy agreements are abolished for new and converted periodic tenancies, so rent increases must follow the statutory Section 13 procedure instead. Tenants can challenge the proposed increase at the First-tier Tribunal (Property Chamber), and the tribunal can no longer set a rent higher than the landlord proposed, removing a previous deterrent to challenging unfair increases.
actions_tenant: Check that any rent increase has been given on the official Section 13 form, with at least two months' notice and no more than one increase in any 12-month period.
Compare the proposed new rent with similar properties in your area using online listings and local agents to see if it reflects a fair market level.
If you believe the increase is too high, apply to the First-tier Tribunal (Property Chamber) before the date the new rent is due to start, using the form and guidance on the government website.
Continue paying your current rent on time while the tribunal is considering your application, and keep written proof of all payments.
Contact Shelter (0808 800 4444) or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) for help in assessing whether the increase is fair and in completing the tribunal forms.
actions_landlord: Use the correct Section 13 notice form and give the tenant at least two months' written notice of any proposed rent increase.
Ensure you only increase the rent once in any 12-month period for a periodic assured tenancy and that the new rent is in line with local market levels.
Avoid relying on old rent review clauses in tenancy agreements, as these are abolished for converted periodic tenancies and increases must follow the statutory Section 13 route.
Explain to the tenant in writing how you have arrived at the new rent and be prepared to justify it to the First-tier Tribunal if the increase is challenged.

documents.title: Tenancy Deposit Protection Requirements
documents.content: For most assured tenancies in England, a landlord must protect a tenancy deposit in a government-approved scheme within 30 days of receiving it, in line with Sections 213-215 of the Housing Act 2004. The three approved schemes are the Deposit Protection Service (DPS), MyDeposits and the Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS), each offering custodial and insurance-backed options. The landlord must also provide the tenant with prescribed information about the scheme within the same 30-day period. If they fail to do so, the tenant can bring a claim in the county court for between one and three times the deposit amount as a penalty, and the landlord may face restrictions on recovering possession, while any agreed deductions must be dealt with and any undisputed amount returned within 10 days, with free dispute resolution available through the scheme.
actions_tenant: Ask your landlord or agent which deposit scheme they used and request the certificate and prescribed information if you have not already received it.
Check directly with DPS, MyDeposits or TDS using their websites to see if your deposit is registered in your name and at the correct address.
If the deposit was not protected within 30 days or you did not receive the prescribed information, write a formal letter or email to your landlord raising this breach and asking them to remedy it.
Consider making a claim in the county court for a penalty of one to three times the deposit if the landlord has failed to comply, seeking legal advice or help from Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848).
At the end of the tenancy, use the scheme's free dispute resolution service if you disagree with proposed deductions, and provide photos, inventories and receipts to support your case.
actions_landlord: Protect every qualifying tenancy deposit within 30 days of receipt in one of the approved schemes: DPS, MyDeposits or TDS.
Provide the tenant with the full prescribed information, including scheme details and how disputes will be handled, within the same 30-day period.
At the end of the tenancy, agree deductions promptly in writing and arrange for any undisputed deposit balance to be returned within 10 days.
Use the scheme's alternative dispute resolution process if you and the tenant cannot agree on deductions, and keep good records such as inventories, photos and invoices.
Be aware that failing to protect a deposit correctly can lead to a court order to pay the tenant one to three times the deposit amount and may restrict your ability to regain possession.

documents.title: Landlord Repair Duties and Awaab's Law
documents.content: Section 11 of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985 requires landlords to keep in repair the structure and exterior of the dwelling, and to maintain installations for water, gas, electricity, sanitation, space heating and hot water. Following the introduction of Awaab's Law, new regulations set specific timeframes for investigating and remedying serious hazards such as damp and mould, and these standards are extended to many private rented homes under the Renters' Rights Act 2025. The Decent Homes Standard is also applied to the private rented sector for the first time, meaning properties must be free from serious hazards, warm, safe and in a reasonable state of repair. Tenants can report serious disrepair and health risks to the local council's environmental health team if the landlord fails to act, which may lead to enforcement notices and penalties.
actions_tenant: Report all repair problems to your landlord or agent in writing (email or letter), clearly describing the issue and how it affects you, and keep a copy.
Allow reasonable access for inspections and repair works, but ask for at least 24 hours' notice for non-emergency visits where possible.

For non-emergency issues, allow a reasonable time for works to start and be completed, typically 14-28 days depending on severity; for emergencies such as total loss of heating in winter or dangerous electrics, insist on action within 24 hours.
Take dated photos or videos of damp, mould, leaks, damaged fixtures and any health impacts, and keep a diary of when you reported problems and any responses.
If the landlord ignores written reports or refuses to carry out necessary works, contact your local council's environmental health or private sector housing team and ask for an inspection.
Remember: Do NOT withhold rent — use formal complaint routes, council enforcement and the Housing Ombudsman service instead of stopping payments.
actions_landlord: Set up a clear system to receive and log repair reports from tenants and respond promptly, prioritising serious hazards such as damp, mould, gas leaks and unsafe electrics.
Arrange inspections and works within legally required timeframes under Awaab's Law and related regulations, ensuring emergencies are dealt with within 24 hours where necessary.
Ensure the property meets the Decent Homes Standard, including being free from serious hazards, adequately heated and in a reasonable state of repair.
Keep records of all repair requests, inspections and works, including invoices and photos, to demonstrate compliance if challenged by the council or a tribunal.
Cooperate fully with environmental health officers and comply with any improvement notices or orders to avoid enforcement action and financial penalties.

documents.title: Periodic Tenancies after Abolition of Fixed-Term ASTs
documents.content: Assured shorthold tenancies are abolished and most private rented tenancies in England become open-ended periodic assured tenancies under the Renters' Rights Act 2025. These tenancies do not have a fixed end date and continue indefinitely until the tenant gives valid notice or the landlord obtains a court order for possession. Tenants can usually end a periodic tenancy by giving at least two months' written notice at any time, with no minimum term or break clause required, while the existing rent and other terms continue unless lawfully varied. Landlords must follow the statutory eviction process and cannot simply insist that a tenant leaves at the end of an old fixed term or arbitrary date in the contract.
actions_tenant: Check your tenancy agreement and any recent letters, but remember that most private tenancies are now periodic and do not automatically end on a fixed date.
When you decide to move, give your landlord at least two months' written notice, stating the date your notice will end and keep a copy of the email or letter.
Continue paying rent and complying with your obligations until the end of your notice period, and agree arrangements for a check-out inspection and return of your deposit.
If a landlord tells you that you must leave just because an old fixed term has ended, seek advice from Shelter (0808 800 4444) or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) before agreeing to go.
If you want to stay, simply continue paying rent on time; you do not need to sign a new fixed-term agreement unless you choose to.
actions_landlord: Recognise that most existing assured shorthold tenancies convert to periodic assured tenancies and do not automatically end on a calendar date.
Update your documents and communications so they reflect periodic tenancies and do not wrongly state that a tenant must leave at the end of an old fixed term.
If a tenant gives notice, confirm acceptance in writing, agree the move-out date, and arrange a fair check-out and deposit return in line with deposit protection rules.
If you wish to regain possession, follow the correct legal process (usually using Section 8 grounds) and obtain a court order instead of relying on contract clauses alone.

documents.title: Right to Request Pets in Rented Homes
documents.content: Under reforms introduced by the Renters' Rights Act 2025, tenants have a statutory right to request permission to keep a pet in their rented home and landlords must not unreasonably refuse such requests. Landlords are required to respond in writing within 42 days of receiving a written pet request, giving clear reasons if they refuse; if they fail to respond in time, consent is treated as automatically granted. Blanket 'no pets' clauses in tenancy agreements are no longer enforceable, although landlords can require that the tenant obtains and maintains suitable pet damage insurance instead of charging a separate pet deposit.

sources.title: Housing Act 1988 (as amended by Renters' Rights Act 2025)

actions_tenant: Make your pet request in writing, describing the animal (such as dog, cat, age, size and breed) and how you will care for it and prevent damage.
Refer to your right to request a pet under the Renters' Rights Act 2025 and state the date of your request so the 42-day response period is clear.
Keep copies of your request and any replies, including emails or messages, in case there is a dispute later about whether permission was granted.
If your landlord does not respond within 42 days, write again confirming that consent is treated as given by law and asking them to confirm any reasonable conditions, such as pet damage insurance.
If your request is refused and you believe the reasons are unreasonable, seek advice from Shelter (0808 800 4444) or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) about challenging the decision.
actions_landlord: Set up a clear process to receive and log pet requests from tenants and respond in writing within the 42-day legal time limit.
Consider each request on its individual merits, avoiding blanket 'no pets' bans, and only refuse where you have specific, reasonable grounds such as property type or serious allergy risks.
Where you grant permission, confirm any reasonable conditions in writing, such as a requirement for the tenant to hold pet damage insurance and to repair any damage caused.
If you refuse, give clear written reasons that are likely to be considered reasonable if later scrutinised by an ombudsman or tribunal.

documents.title: Protection from Discrimination in Renting
documents.content: It is unlawful under the Equality Act 2010 for landlords and letting agents to discriminate against prospective or existing tenants on protected grounds such as disability, race, sex, religion or belief, sexual orientation, pregnancy and maternity, or age. County court cases have found that blanket bans on tenants receiving benefits, such as adverts stating 'No DSS' or refusing applicants on Universal Credit, can amount to indirect discrimination, and similar concerns arise with blanket bans on tenants with children. The Renters' Rights Act 2025 reinforces these protections by making clear that landlords and agents must assess each applicant individually on their merits rather than applying blanket exclusions, and breaches can lead to complaints to the Housing Ombudsman, enforcement by regulators, and potential claims for damages.
actions_tenant: Keep copies or screenshots of any adverts, emails or messages that use phrases like 'No DSS', 'no benefits', or 'no children', or that suggest you are being rejected because of a protected characteristic.
Ask the landlord or agent in writing to explain the reasons for refusal and whether they assessed your individual circumstances, including income and references.
Contact Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848), Shelter (0808 800 4444) or an equality advice service to assess whether you may have grounds for a discrimination claim.
If you believe you have been discriminated against, make a formal complaint to the agent's redress scheme or the Housing Ombudsman and consider seeking legal advice about a county court claim.
Inform your local council's housing or enforcement team if an agent or landlord repeatedly advertises with discriminatory wording so they can monitor and take action.
actions_landlord: Review all adverts, application forms and policies to remove blanket bans such as 'No DSS', 'no benefits' or 'no children', and ensure they comply with the Equality Act 2010.
Assess each applicant individually based on affordability, references and lawful criteria, and record your reasons for decisions in case they are later challenged.
Train staff and agents on equality and diversity obligations and the risks of indirect discrimination in how they select and communicate with tenants.
Respond promptly and constructively to any complaints or concerns about discrimination, and seek legal advice if you are unsure whether a proposed policy is lawful.

documents.title: Private Rented Sector Landlord Registration Database
documents.content: The Renters' Rights Act 2025 establishes a national Private Rented Sector Database that requires all landlords to register themselves and each rented property they control. The database is intended to be publicly searchable by tenants, allowing them to check that a landlord is registered and to view key compliance information such as licensing status and past enforcement action. Local authorities use the database to target inspections and enforcement, and failure to register or to keep information up to date can result in civil financial penalties and restrictions on certain landlord rights. Detailed rules on how to register, fees and launch timings are being finalised in secondary legislation, but landlords should prepare by gathering accurate information about their portfolio.

sources.title: Housing Act 1988 (as amended by Renters' Rights Act 2025)

actions_tenant: Use the national Private Rented Sector Database or official property portal (once live) to search for your landlord and rental address before or during your tenancy.
If you cannot find your landlord or property on the register, raise this with your landlord in writing and ask them to confirm that they have registered correctly.
Report concerns about an unregistered landlord or serious compliance issues to your local council's private rented sector or enforcement team.
Take screenshots or printouts from the database showing any history of enforcement action or licensing issues and consider this information when deciding whether to rent or renew.
Contact Shelter (0808 800 4444) or Citizens Advice (0800 144 8848) if you are worried about your landlord's compliance or about possible retaliation for raising registration concerns.
actions_landlord: Register yourself and each rented property you own or manage on the national Private Rented Sector Database within the timescales set by the implementing regulations.
Keep your registration details up to date, including ownership changes, licensing status and contact information, so that tenants and councils can rely on accurate information.
Monitor guidance from the government and your local authority on registration requirements, fees and penalties, and budget for any registration costs.
Understand that failure to register or to keep information accurate may lead to civil penalties and could be taken into account in future enforcement or licensing decisions.
